awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Upward Sun River (Xaasaa Na') Exploratory Excavation
awd_abstract_narration: This project consists of excavation of a residential structure associated with a burial/cremation pit feature, well-dated to 10,000 RCYBP (~11,500 calendar years ago) found by our team last summer at Upward Sun River (Xaasaa Na?) (49XBD-298), a multi-component site in the Tanana Basin, central Alaska. The feature is in buried contexts, over 1 meter below surface, in deposits relatively undisturbed by cryoturbation. After consultation with federal, state, and Native officials (stipulated in the Section 106 MOA), all parties agreed to excavation of the feature.  Four additional features (to the burial/cremation pit) have been observed to date, and all appear to be outdoor unlined firepits. This proposed excavation is designed to excavate the residential structure, and collect additional geoarchaeological samples to increase our knowledge of site formation, post-depositional disturbance, technology, and subsistence, as well as to specifically evaluate the child cremation to the rest of the structure. At present, no burials have been found in Late Pleistocene/Early Holocene contexts in Eastern Beringia, so our knowledge of an entire suite of mortuary-related behaviors is essentially unknown. This excavation has the potential to contribute transformative data to our understanding of this time period in the Western Hemisphere.

This research involved continued excavation in 2011 at the Upward Sun River site (USR) and was designed to accomplish two objectives: (1) identify activities occurring within the 11,500 year-old residential structure, the earliest found in northern North America, and (2) document house shape and size, construction, and use history. Only a handful of residential structures exist for the earliest period of occupation in North America (greater than 10,000 years ago), and the USR feature contributes greatly to our understanding of these ancient lifeways.

In summer, 2010, we discovered ancient human remains, designated 'Xaa Saa Cheeg'e Ts'eniin' by local Native Athabaskans, in the Tanana basin, central Alaska. Following our legal agreements with local and regional Native Alaskans, we excavated the burial, which turned out to be a cremation within a central hearth within a residential structure. This funding (year 2011) was used to partially support the excavation of this residential structure, and was designed to accomplish two objectives: (1) identify activities occurring within the 11,500 year-old residential structure, the earliest found in northern North America, and (2) document structure shape and size, construction, and use history.

Analyses are ongoing, but all of the research objectives have been met, and the initial findings include the following. We have completely excavated the feature, providing dimension (~4 m in diameter and about 13.5 m2 in area). The structure is similar in size to those Paleolithic structures previously found in Russia. Two discrete stone tool activity areas were identified, along with an area devoid of stone tool debris, suggesting multiple activity areas within the structure. Additional tools were identified, all consistent with earlier finds, including what appear to be domestic tools (i.e., no associated hunting tools were recovered). The entire structure may have been burned after the child cremation. No evidence of structure re-use was identified.

Paleoindian residential features are very rare (only ~6 in the Western Hemisphere), and we could not previously evaluate this source of variability in early forager lifeways in eastern Beringia (Alaska, Yukon Territory, and the Bering land bridge which were connected in the last Ice Age). However, with the confirmed presence of young children and almost certainly females at USR, we can begin analysis of social organization. The mixed foraging group and broad spectrum diet inferred from USR can be contrasted with the logistically ortganized hunting parties and economic specialization of large ungulates represented at other Paleoindian sites.

USR residential structure data can be compared with known Paleoindian houses: all have similar small sizes, with little size variation. The similarities betwen these sites suggest generalizations about small co-residing group sizes of early Paleoindians. There is no evidence at USR for larger, segmented residential structures like those at Kostienki, argued to reflect communal aggregations and/or more complex social structure. In terms of area, the USR structure (and the Paleoindian structures) is similar to ethnographically known house sizes in the subarctic, with number of potential occupants estimated at ~4 persons. These data are consistent with Siberian data on the colonizers of far northeast Siberia (Diuktai Culture), who exhibit toolstone conservation, rapid expansion, and homogeneity of toolkits - all suggestive of very high residential mobility and low co-residing populations.

The completed excavation of the residential structure allows for a clearer understanding of human lifeways in northern North America.
